messages.content: I went to bed last night around 9 p.m. and then today I woke up around 6.30 a.m. In the meantime, I woke up around 12 to 1 a.m. because yesterday I had a migraine, but I woke up and it felt clear. I also just said that when I woke up between 12 to 1, I couldn't fall back to sleep, so I used another 12.5 milligram dose to help sleep. I don't know, I think it took me like two hours to fall back to sleep possibly. And then after waking up, I went to just get a bit of sunlight. At the same time, I finished my first water bottle with electrolyte packet, half of the packet. And before that, I drank about eight ounces of plain water. And then just to avoid mistakes, I actually immediately took the morning supplements, including fish oil, magnesium, and B2. That's it. Right now I feel fine. There's no pain or anything like that.

How would you rate sleep quality (1-10)? Quick double-check: have you taken Pantoprazole/Famotidine yet, and how much protein/Vit D/Ca have you had so far today? Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?
can you show me as a table format ?

between 08:20 - 09:00 am, I did switch game fitness + zumba , cardio , feeling good afterwards

It's 1044 a.m. So about 20 minutes ago, I started looking at our emails and realized we have to pay for a property tax of $7,000 by September. And I just realized my last paycheck probably is just that money. I don't know, like a very kind of low financial stress by looking at the money expenses I have here. So I felt like a tiny bit of pain on my right scapula. And then I decided to apply some slump pass patches. And now I'm like resting on the bed, listening to waves, white noise. The pain level is low, probably 1. There's some kind of tension on my temple, 0.5 tension, right temple.

Log saved FieldDetailsTime10:44MoodMild financial stress, restingStress 0-10?Right-migraine pain 0-100.5 (temple tension)Notes / hormones / weatherRight-scapula ache 1/10 after tax e-mail → applied Salonpas patch; white-noise relaxation Reflections Shoulder/temple tension is a common “early-warning” stress signal; try 60 sec of slow shoulder-blade squeezes followed by 4-7-8 breathing to head it off. Quick check-ins: a) what number would you put on stress right now (0-10)? b) how many additional ounces of fluid have you had since the workout so I can update hydration? Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?

Right now it's 12.45am. We went out for lunch around 11.30am. I had a blackened fish taco and a steak taco at Cal Tortilla. And then later we went down to Waggy Man's for shopping groceries. In the restaurant, Jack and I had a fight. A small fight. That raised my kind of emotional level from 0 to 1, that kind of way. I don't know. He kept calling me a.... He thinks me being an anxious person and anxiety that got me upset. It's not a big deal. I immediately applied the SalonPass patches on my neck to try to calm it down and apply the essential oil. It's super hot outside. I'm hoping to chill until I need to go to a physical therapist today at 3pm.

Now make a correction on the hydration. It's literally, I only had another 32 ounces, not 64. And also, I forgot to drink the coffee I made, so I knew I would just finish the coffee, which is 6 ounces pour over, with 8 grams of medium roast, coarsely grinded coffee.

Reflux-food tally now = 3 (> 2/day). Balance dinner with gentle options (e.g., grilled veggies, plain rice, lean protein) and skip mint/tomato tonight to ward off evening burn. Kind of stress is zero. I was wondering about the coffee because it's pretty late now. I normally have it around, I don't know, 8 a.m. somewhere like that.

Log saved FieldDetailsStress 0-100 Reflections Nice rebound—stress back to baseline. Late-day coffee can still linger (caffeine half-life ≈ 5 h) and may nudge both reflux and sleep quality; consider a noon cut-off or switch to decaf after lunch. With reflux-food tally at 3, a gentle, low-acid dinner and upright posture after meals will help keep evening burn in check. Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?

Okay, between 3-4 pm; I did a physical therapist on my neck, which is awesome, amazing. It has basically, I'm gonna, Mike helped to do some indirect muscle release during the session, and then I was pressing the trigger point, and then do some kind of inverse stretch there. It was really good. And then later, I did a heart therapy, where they also kind of connected a little bit, a little bit of kind of a electric stuff, like a thingy that attached to the back of my neck. That was really helpful. And then it's moist. Oh, that feels great. I was having some attention on my right side before I go. Now it's like kind of a gum. I still have some tiny tension on my right scapula, but then it feels great. I think that it's gonna be really helpful moving forward.

Log saved FieldDetailsExercisePT neck session 15:00-16:00 (manual release + trigger-point work, e-stim, moist heat)Right-migraine pain 0-100Notes / hormones / weatherRight-scapula tension ↓ to 0.5; feeling relaxed Reflections Neck feels looser—lock in gains with PT’s home set: 30 sec doorway pec stretch × 3, gentle chin tucks 10-rep sets, 2-3 × day. Rehydrate (~12 oz) and add a light protein-plus-potassium snack (banana + Greek yogurt) to speed muscle recovery and stave off evening reflux. Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?

I had my dinner between 5.30 to 6 p.m. and spring roll, rice crisps, and gravy noodle, fried tofu, cheese, carrots, and also lettuce. And the dipping sauce is made of peanut butter, water, white rice vinegar, and two teaspoons of soy sauce and garlic.

Log saved FieldDetailsNotes / hormones / weatherDay 3 of natural-light + music/podcast wind-down practice Reflections Consistent light-and-sound wind-down trains your circadian clock; if you track sleep latency, notice whether it’s shortening after a week. Keep screens dim/off 30 min before bed to amplify the calming cue—and don’t forget tonight’s 20:00 amitriptyline. Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?
Also note that it would be day 1 of amitriptyline

Log saved FieldDetailsNotes / hormones / weatherDay 1 of amitriptyline (planned 25 mg at 20:00) Reflections First-night dose—track any dry-mouth, vivid dreams, or next-morning grogginess for the first week so we can spot patterns early (Megahandout p18). When you actually swallow the pill, drop the exact time so we log it accurately and start the 30-day count-down for migraine-prevention review. Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?
And also day 1 of PT

Log saved FieldDetailsNotes / hormones / weatherDay 1 of PT program logged Reflections Great milestone—note any soreness vs. relief tomorrow morning so your PT can tweak the plan at session 2. Combine tonight’s gentle neck stretches with the new amitriptyline to prime restful sleep and muscle recovery. Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?
My doctors prescribed me emegality pen for injection and should I do it tomorrow after PT? Or maybe Wednesday? Just want to make sure they don’t interfere with each other

Log saved FieldDetailsTask reminderChoose first Emgality (galcanezumab) injection date (tomorrow after PT vs Wednesday) and set monthly alarm Reflections Emgality doesn’t interact with amitriptyline or yesterday’s PT work, so timing is flexible—pick a calm evening (e.g., tomorrow night or Wednesday) and stick with that date each month. Let the pen warm 30 min out of the fridge, inject into thigh/abdomen/upper arm, and jot any site soreness so you can report back at your next visit. Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?
Why it’s those places? I thought it would be neck somewhere?

Log saved FieldDetailsNotes / hormones / weatherEmgality 25 mg pen: inject subcutaneously into abdomen, front-thigh, back-upper-arm, or buttocks (not neck) Reflections Why those spots? Emgality is meant for a subcutaneous (fat-layer) injection. Abdomen, thigh, back of the upper arm, and buttocks all have a smooth pad of fat that: keeps the needle safely away from major neck vessels and nerves, lets the medication absorb at a steady rate, and makes it easy to pinch an inch and inject yourself. The neck has very little sub-Q fat and lots of “don’t-hit-me” structures (carotid artery, jugular, nerves), so manufacturers flag it off-limits. Tips for tomorrow or Wednesday: Let the pen warm to room temp ~30 min. Choose a calm evening, rotate sites each month (e.g., R thigh → L abdomen → R arm…) to avoid soreness. Log the exact time so we can track monthly reminders and any site reactions. Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?
What does emegality pen do?

Log saved FieldDetailsno new tracked data— Reflections – Q&A What Emgality (“emegality” pen) does Purpose → migraine & cluster-headache prevention Emgality is a prescription monoclonal-antibody medicine (generic = galcanezumab-gnlm) taken once a month to reduce the number of headache days, not to stop pain that’s already started. In studies, about half of patients cut monthly migraine days by ≥ 50 %. How it works During a migraine, the neuro-peptide CGRP (calcitonin-gene–related peptide) rises and drives pain-inflammation around brain blood vessels. Emgality binds to CGRP itself, blocking the peptide so it can’t activate pain pathways; think of it as “soaking up the extra CGRP before it sets off the alarm.” Where & when to inject It’s a sub-cutaneous (fat-layer) shot—sites with a safe pinch of fat and few vital structures: front thigh, abdomen (2″ from navel), back of upper arm, or upper outer buttock. Rotate spots monthly to avoid soreness; never the neck, which has almost no fat and many important vessels/nerves. Dosing roadmap Loading: two 120-mg pens (240 mg total) on day 1, unless your neurologist chose a 120 mg start. Maintenance: one 120-mg pen every 30 ± 3 days. Setting a standing calendar alert helps. Onset & monitoring Relief can start within the first month, but full benefit may take 2-3 months. Track monthly migraine-day counts to judge effect. Side-effects are usually mild—most often injection-site redness/itch, occasional constipation or mild antibody rash; anaphylaxis is rare but requires ER care. Interactions Emgality is not metabolised by the liver and doesn’t significantly interact with amitriptyline, pantoprazole, or PT treatments, so you can pick whichever calm evening (tomorrow or Wednesday) fits best. Next step Choose your “day 0” (post-PT tomorrow or Wednesday), let the pen warm 30 min, inject, and log the exact time plus any site reaction so we can add it to your tracker. Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?
It's 7.59. I just took the amitriptyline.

Log saved FieldDetailsAmitriptyline mg (time)25 mg at 19:59 Reflections First dose logged—keep a note of sleep-onset time, any vivid dreams, and morning grogginess so we can see how you respond over the next week. A small glass of water now and bedside hydration can curb the dry-mouth that sometimes comes with amitriptyline. Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?
should i take it 1 hour before bed time or later ?

Log saved FieldDetailsTask reminderTarget amitriptyline 25 mg ≈ 1–2 h before planned sleep; adjust earlier if groggy Reflections Amitriptyline starts to feel sedating in ~30–60 min, peaks by 2 h, and lasts through the night—so taking it around 7:30-8 p.m. (for a 9-9:30 p.m. lights-out) usually balances drowsiness with next-morning clarity. If you still feel foggy on waking after a few nights, slide the dose 30 min earlier; if you’re sleepy too soon, move it closer to bedtime—consistency is key, so stick to the time that feels best after a week-long trial. Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?
Um, started my first yawning at 8.15pm.

Log saved FieldDetailsNotes / hormones / weatherFirst amitriptyline effect: yawning began 20:15 Reflections Nice marker—sedation kicking in ~15 min after dose suggests the 7:59 p.m. timing lines up well with a 9 p.m. lights-out; keep noting yawning or heaviness times for a week to fine-tune. If you find yourself nodding off too early, shift the pill 15-30 min later; if still wide-awake at 9:30 p.m., move it earlier—consistency is key once you lock the sweet spot. Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?
um also just um there's a tiny bit of pain 0.5 on the right tempo there um yeah feel slightly lightheaded

If dizziness ≥ 3/10 or worsens, note the exact time and consider calling your clinician for guidance. Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?
Also just want to make a note that today there's no pain on the left top scalp at all.

Keep an eye on whether the scalp-pain stays at 0 tomorrow; if it resurfaces, jot time + possible triggers so we can fine-tune PT homework. Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?

Oh, I don't think it's related to the PT at all. It just simply doesn't exist. I mean, the left top scalp pain was only existing a few days ago. And then I think since yesterday it has dialed down. I have no idea because I don't think it's something particularly related to the migraine I have. It's something new, possibly physically related to the tension on the left side. I mean, despite that I do have tension on the left side, so I don't know.

Keep left-side stretches gentle tonight; if scalp pain stays nil over the next 3 days we’ll mark it as resolved. Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?

Log saved FieldDetails—(no new data – compiling requested summary) Reflections Full daily entry – 2025-07-29 FieldDetailsDate2025-07-29LocationFrederick, MDWeather (high ≈ 101 °F)Sunny a.m.; very hot afternoonBed time HH:MM21:00 (night of 7-28 → 7-29)Wake time HH:MM06:30Sleep hours / Quality6.5 h / 4-5Hydration oz (electrolytes)104 oz (½-packet in evening)Morning-light minbrief (~10 min)Meals & times07:30 – 1 c cereal + 1 c 1 % milk • 09:50 – same • 11:30 – blackened fish taco + steak taco • 13:00 – 6 oz black coffee • 17:30-18:00 – spring roll, rice crisps, gravy-noodle w/ fried tofu + cheese, carrots & lettuce (+ peanut-soy-vinegar-garlic dip)Calories / Protein / Carbs / Added-Sugar≈ 2114 kcal / 105 g / 241 g / 29 gVit D IU / Ca mg~268 IU / ~817 mgExercise08:20-09:00 Switch Fit + Zumba cardio (40 min) • 15:00-16:00 PT neck sessionPosture breaks—Stress 0-10 (peak)1 (argument at lunch) → 0 eveningMoodGood overall; mild midday upsetPantoprazoleY 06:40FamotidineY 18:00Doxylamine12.5 mg (≈ 00:30)Amitriptyline25 mg 19:59 (⁠day 1)SupplementsFish-oil ×2, Magnesium ×2, B-2; evening multiRight-migraine pain 0-100 → 0.5 (20:20) → 0Left-headache 0-100Scalp-pain 0-100Left-neck tension 0-101 pre-bed → 0 (20:55)Asthma sxnoneReflux sx (regurgitation)1-2 (20:15)Rescue inhaler uses0NotesDay 1 PT program • Day 1 amitriptyline • Plan first Emgality injection (t-2 or Wed) • Day 3 natural-light wind-downEpisode ID link— Two quick take-aways Reflux review: four triggers (spicy tacos, fatty tofu/noodles, coffee, peanut/soy) + evening regurgitation 1-2/5. Try a lighter, low-acid breakfast tomorrow (e.g., oatmeal + egg whites) and keep upright ≥ 90 min after the evening meal to see if the score stays ≤ 1. Vitamin D / Calcium gap: totals landed at ≈ 268 IU D and ≈ 817 mg Ca (< 600 IU / 1 000 mg targets). A midday walk + a fortified-milk or yogurt snack could close both gaps without extra pills. Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?
